<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 277, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 343, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
May/June 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A javelin thrower noted the lengths of a random sample of 50 of her throws. The sample mean was \(72.3 \text{m}\) and an unbiased estimate of the population variance was \(64.3 \text{m}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 918, 140]]<|/det|>
Find a \(92\%\) confidence interval for the population mean length of throws by this athlete. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 660, 185, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 660, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
A discus thrower wishes to calculate a \(92\%\) confidence interval for the population mean length of his throws. He bases his calculation on his first 50 throws in a week.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 704, 368, 722]]<|/det|>
Comment on this method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 704, 920, 722]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
In the past, the mean height of plants of a particular species has been \(2.3 \text{m}\). A random sample of 60 plants of this species was treated with fertiliser and the mean height of these 60 plants was found to be \(2.4 \text{m}\). Assume that the standard deviation of the heights of plants treated with fertiliser is \(0.4 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Carry out a test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level of whether the mean height of plants treated with fertiliser is greater than \(2.3 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
The number of cars arriving at a certain road junction on a weekday morning has a Poisson distribution with mean 4.6 per minute. Traffic lights are installed at the junction and a council officer wishes to test at the \(2\%\) significance level whether there are now fewer cars arriving. He notes the number of cars arriving during a randomly chosen 2-minute period.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 152, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 611, 170]]<|/det|>
State suitable null and alternative hypotheses for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 327, 148, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 327, 437, 346]]<|/det|>
Find the critical region for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 327, 920, 346]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The officer notes that, during a randomly chosen 2-minute period on a weekday morning, exactly 5 cars arrive at the junction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 304, 138]]<|/det|>
Carry out the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 327, 144, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 327, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, whether it is possible that a Type I error has been made in carrying out the test in part (c).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 483, 920, 517]]<|/det|>
The number of cars arriving at another junction on a weekday morning also has a Poisson distribution with mean 4.6 per minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 529, 146, 547]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 529, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find the probability that more than 300 cars will arrive at this junction in an hour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 543, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 618, 92]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 98, 638, 139]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{3}{16} (4x - x^2) & 2\leqslant x\leqslant 4,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 160, 146, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 159, 331, 178]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{E}(X) = \frac{11}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 160, 920, 178]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 504, 178, 522]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 504, 265, 522]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{Var}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 574, 91]]<|/det|>
Given that the median of \(X\) is \(m\), find \(\mathrm{P}(m< X< 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The masses, in kilograms, of large and small sacks of grain have the distributions N(53, 11) and N(14, 3) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the mass of a randomly chosen large sack is greater than four times the mass of a randomly chosen small sack.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 573, 92]]<|/det|>
A lift can safely carry a maximum mass of \(1000\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the lift can safely carry 12 randomly chosen large sacks and 25 randomly chosen small sacks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 888, 92]]<|/det|>
\(X\) is a random variable with distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(2.90)\). A random sample of 100 values of \(X\) is taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 589, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the sample mean is less than 2.88.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
